name: Meta
title: Meta Superintelligence Labs — 4-Unit Consolidation

classification.classificationRationale: RECLASSIFIED from Model 1 (Research Lab) to Model 4 (Hybrid/Hub-and-Spoke). The Oct 2025 restructuring consolidated Meta's AI into a 4-unit Meta Superintelligence Labs (MSL) under Alexandr Wang: (1) TBD Lab (LLMs), (2) FAIR (long-term research), (3) Products & Applied Research, (4) MSL Infra. This is a classic hub-and-spoke with MSL as the hub and 4 specialized units as spokes. FAIR retains as secondary Model 1 element but is now subordinated to product-driven leadership. The departure of chief scientist LeCun signals that pure research autonomy was sacrificed for product coordination. High confidence: 8+ sources with detailed structural information.

description:
Meta reorganized its AI division into Meta Superintelligence Labs (MSL) with 4 units: (1) TBD Lab (LLMs including Llama), (2) FAIR (long-term research), (3) Products & Applied Research (led by Nat Friedman, former GitHub CEO), and (4) MSL Infrastructure. The consolidation is led by Alexandr Wang (28, founder/former CEO of Scale AI), whom Meta appointed as Chief AI Officer after acquiring a 49% stake in Scale AI for $14.3 billion.

In October 2025, Meta cut approximately 600 positions from MSL but notably spared the TBD Lab unit. Wang's internal memo explained: 'By reducing the size of our team, fewer conversations will be required to make a decision, and each person will be more load-bearing and have more scope and impact.'

The restructuring triggered the departure of Yann LeCun (Turing Award winner, Meta's Chief AI Scientist for 12 years), who publicly stated: 'You don't tell a researcher what to do. You certainly don't tell a researcher like me what to do.' LeCun left to found AMI Labs, pursuing alternative AI approaches (world models via V-JEPA). The departure represents a fundamental tension: Meta shifted from protecting long-term research autonomy (FAIR under LeCun) to subordinating research to product-driven commercial objectives (MSL under Wang).

Meta is aggressively recruiting AI talent: 11 new researchers from DeepMind, OpenAI, and Anthropic, with Zuckerberg personally recruiting at his homes. New model roadmap includes Mango (image/video) and Avocado (text/reasoning) for H1 2026. Separately, Stratechery reported Meta is retreating from Reality Labs to fund AI infrastructure ('Meta Compute').

mechanisms.name: Merge Competing AI Teams Under Single Leader
mechanisms.evidence: Previous dual-track (GenAI under Chris Cox + FAIR under LeCun) consolidated into 4-unit MSL under single leader Alexandr Wang. Multiple reshuffles in rapid succession.

mechanisms.name: Protect Off-Strategy Work
mechanisms.evidence: COUNTER-EXAMPLE: Meta FAILED to protect off-strategy research. LeCun's departure demonstrates what happens when exploration (FAIR) is subordinated to execution (product-driven MSL). Research autonomy sacrificed for coordination.

taxonomyFeedback: RECLASSIFICATION: Model 1 → Model 4. Meta's evolution demonstrates how a Research Lab model can be subordinated to a Hub-and-Spoke model when product urgency overrides research autonomy. LeCun's departure is a clear signal of this transition.

Meta is a powerful counter-example for Mechanism #1 (Protect Off-Strategy Work): when the CEO stops protecting research autonomy, the chief scientist leaves and the research lab loses its independence.

The 'repeated reorgs' pattern (Puck: 'Why Did Meta Reorganize Its AI Unit... Again?') suggests organizational instability as a cost of rapid strategic pivots. The taxonomy doesn't capture the costs of excessive structural flexibility.
